title: Northern celestial hemisphere
text:
The northern celestial hemisphere, also called the Northern Sky, is the <a href="Northern%20Hemisphere">northern half</a> of the <a href="celestial%20sphere">celestial sphere</a>; that is, it lies <a href="north">north</a> of the <a href="celestial%20equator">celestial equator</a>. This arbitrary sphere <a href="diurnal%20motion">appears to rotate</a> westward around a <a href="celestial%20pole">polar axis</a> due to <a href="Earth%27s%20rotation">Earth's rotation</a>.
At any given time, the entire Northern Sky is visible from the geographic <a href="North%20Pole">North Pole</a>, while less of this hemisphere is visible the <a href="latitude">further south</a> the observer is located. The southern counterpart is the <a href="southern%20celestial%20hemisphere">southern celestial hemisphere</a>.
Astronomy.
In the context of <a href="astronomical">astronomical</a> discussions or writing about <a href="celestial%20cartography">celestial cartography</a>, this celestial hemisphere may also simply then be referred to as the Northern Hemisphere.
For the purpose of <a href="star%20chart">celestial mapping</a>, astronomers may conceive the sky as the inside of a <a href="sphere">sphere</a> divided into two halves by the <a href="celestial%20equator">celestial equator</a>. The Northern Sky or Northern Hemisphere is therefore the half of the <a href="celestial%20sphere">celestial sphere</a> that is north of the celestial equator.
Even if this <a href="geocentric%20model">geocentric model</a> is the ideal <a href="map%20projection">projection</a> of the terrestrial <a href="equator">equator</a> onto the imaginary celestial sphere, the northern and southern celestial hemispheres are not to be confused with descriptions of the terrestrial <a href="hemispheres%20of%20Earth">hemispheres</a> of <a href="Earth">Earth</a> itself.
